title: 110_hr6249
content: The Act may be cited as the "Helping Home Owners Make Energy-Efficiency Residential Upgrades Now Act of 2008" or the "H-HOMERUN Act of 2008". It establishes a Residential Energy Efficiency Direct Loan Program. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will establish a program for direct loans to fund energy efficiency improvements in single family housing, including solar heating, cooling systems, residential energy conservation measures, photovoltaic systems, geothermal heat pumps, residential wind turbines, and green roofs. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will establish a program for direct loans to fund energy efficiency improvements in single family housing, including solar heating, cooling systems, residential energy conservation measures, photovoltaic systems, geothermal heat pumps, residential wind turbines, and green roofs. Loan eligibility requirements include a contract with the borrower and full repayment of the loan principal. The program offers direct loans for energy efficiency improvements in single-family housing, with eligibility requirements including a contract with the borrower and full repayment of the principal amount. Loans have a fixed interest rate, must meet an investment requirement of at least 5% of the improvement cost, and adhere to credit underwriting standards set by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish credit underwriting standards for evaluating borrower eligibility for loans. The Secretary will determine property value for loan security and repayment will be in monthly installments. Loans must be used for energy efficiency improvements on the borrower's principal residence. The Secretary will establish credit underwriting standards for evaluating borrower eligibility for loans, with repayment in monthly installments. Direct loans made under this section shall be subject to other terms as required by the Secretary. Energy efficiency improvements for single-family housing must have a total present value cost lower than the energy saved over the improvement's useful life. The cost and energy savings of the improvement will be determined for this purpose. Energy savings of the improvement shall be determined through a home energy rating report based on a physical inspection by an approved energy consultant. The inspection and determination must be done by a certified individual. Single family housing is defined as a residential structure with 1 to 4 dwelling units. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. Authorized appropriations are available for direct loans under this section for fiscal years 2009 to 2019. The total outstanding principal balance of these loans cannot exceed $100 billion. HUD Energy Efficient Mortgage Program Amendments. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 is amended to remove limitations on cost-effective energy efficiency improvements financed by energy efficient mortgages. Mortgagors are required to pay at least 5% of the improvements' cost. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 is amended to remove limitations on cost-effective energy efficiency improvements financed by energy efficient mortgages. Mortgagors must pay at least 5% of the improvement costs in cash or its equivalent. The determination of cost-effectiveness is now based on a physical inspection by an approved home energy ratings system or energy consultant. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 is amended to remove limitations on cost-effective energy efficiency improvements financed by energy efficient mortgages. Mortgagors must pay at least 5% of the improvement costs in cash or its equivalent. A physical inspection by an approved home energy ratings system or energy consultant is required to determine cost-effectiveness. Such inspection must be conducted by an individual certified by an appropriate national organization as designated by the Secretary.
